original: A list of frequently asked  Computer Graphics Interview Questions  and Answers are given below.
result: Below is a compilation of commonly asked questions and responses for an interview in the field of Computer Graphics.

original: Computer graphics involves display, manipulation, storage of images, and experimental information for proper visualization.
result: Computer graphics refers to the process of presenting, modifying, and storing visual images and experimental data for effective representation.

A setup for generating digital images and multimedia content using computer technology, comprising of various hardware and software components.

result: Computer graphics play a crucial role in computer-aided design for various purposes.

result: This software is utilized for creating visual representations for various written materials or for preparing slides for presentations.

result: The professional combines various techniques such as 3D modeling, texture mapping, drawing programs, and CAD software to create quality designs.

result: CG techniques have become a widespread tool in the entertainment industry for creating animated movies, television shows and music videos.

original: Computer-generated models of physical, financial, and economical methods are used as educational aids.
result: Educational tools have been developed using computer-generated models to illustrate physical, financial, and economic systems.

original: Following are the difference between vector and raster graphics:
result: The subsequent points highlight the disparities between vector and raster graphics:

original: 1.  Raster or Bitmap images are resolution-dependent because of this, it's not possible to increase or reduce their size without sacrificing on image quality.
result: Raster or Bitmap images are limited by their resolution, which means that resizing them can result in a loss of image quality. Hence, it's crucial to consider the required size of the image before choosing a raster format.

original: While the vector-based display is not dependent on resolution, the range of vector image can be increased or reduced without affecting image quality.
result: The resolution of a vector-based display is not a limiting factor and can be resized without losing image quality. This is because vector images are not made up of pixels, but rather consisting of mathematical equations defining the lines, curves and shapes that make up the image. Therefore, the size of a vector image can be altered as needed while maintaining its clarity and sharpness.

original: 2.  Unlike a raster image, a vector picture can't be used for realistic pictures. This is because vector images are made up of solid-color areas and scientific gradients, so they can't be used to demonstrate the continuous tone of colors in a natural photograph.
result: Vector images are not suitable for creating realistic images, unlike raster images. This is because vector images are constructed using solid-color areas and mathematical gradients, which are unable to accurately recreate the continuous variation of shades and hues found in natural photographs.

original: Refreshing is not necessarily.
result: I cannot rephrase an incomplete sentence. Please provide me with the full context so I can paraphrase it for you.

original: Without flicker, very complex images can be exhibit at very high resolution.
result: Displaying intricate images with high resolution is possible without any flicker. This is because flicker-free displays offer smooth image transitions, allowing for a seamless user experience.

original: Refreshing of the screen is not needed.
result: It is not necessary to refresh the screen.

original: They normally never display color.
result: Typically, they don't exhibit any hues.

original: Selected part of the picture never deleted.
result: A portion of the image was not removed when deleting.

original: It can take quite a few second for composite images while redrawing and eliminating the process.
result: Creating composite images may require significant time as the process involves redrawing and eliminating. This could cause a delay of several seconds.

original: Aspect ratio is the ratio of the vertical points to horizontal points essential to produce equivalent length line in both direction on the screen. An aspect ratio of 3/4 defines that a vertical line plotted with three points has the same length as a horizontal lines plotted with four points.
result: Aspect ratio indicates the proportional relationship between the height and width of a screen, which enables vertical and horizontal lines of equal length to appear visually similar. For instance, an aspect ratio of 3:4 implies that a vertical line drawn with three units has the same length as a horizontal line drawn with four units.

original: Raster graphics are consist of pixels
result: Raster graphics are images comprised of small, individual pixels.

original: Vector graphics are consist of paths
result: Vector graphics are created using paths, rather than pixels, making them scalable without losing quality.

original: Raster image pixels do not include their appearance as to size increases
result: When a raster image is scaled up, its individual pixels do not contain information about how it should look when enlarged.

original: Vector image do retain appearance regardless of estimate.
result: Regardless of the scale at which it is viewed or printed, vector images maintain their visual qualities and do not lose their appearance.

original: Raster graphics are not scalable
result: Raster graphics cannot be resized without compromising their quality.

original: Vector images are scalable
result: Vector graphics can be resized without losing their quality.

original: It is the most straightforward algorithm.
result: The most simple and direct algorithm is the one being referred to.

original: It is a faster process for calculating pixel positions.
result: The method of Bresenham algorithm is known for its efficiency in calculating the positions of pixels at a faster pace as compared to other methods.

original: Floating-point arithmetic in DDA technique is time-consuming.
result: The use of floating-point arithmetic in DDA (Digital Differential Analyzer) method can be a time-consuming process.

original: Endpoint accuracy is poor.
result: The level of precision at the endpoint is unsatisfactory.

original: DDA algorithm uses floating point, i.e., Real Arithmetic's.
result: The DDA algorithm employs Real Arithmetic that deals with floating point numbers.

original: Bresenhams algorithm uses fixed point, i.e., Integer Arithmetic's.
result: Bresenham's algorithm applies integer arithmetic or fixed-point computations to perform its calculations.

original: DDA algorithms uses multiplication and division in its operation.
result: The DDA algorithm utilizes multiplication and division when performing its operations.

original: Bresenhams algorithm use only subtraction and addition in its operations.
result: Bresenham's algorithm is a computational approach that involves utilizing addition and subtraction solely while performing operations.

original: DDA algorithm is slowly than Bresenham's algorithm inline drawing because it uses real arithmetic (floating-point methods).
result: The DDA algorithm for line drawing is known to be slower compared to Bresenham's algorithm because it involves the use of real arithmetic, which relies on floating-point operations.

original: Bresenhams algorithm is faster than the DDA algorithm inline drawing because it performs only addition and subtractions in its calculation and uses only integer arithmetic, so it runs significantly fast.
result: Bresenham's algorithm is a quicker alternative to the DDA algorithm for inline drawing as it utilizes integer arithmetic and only involves addition and subtraction in its calculations, resulting in a significant speed improvement.

original: DDA algorithms is not as accurate and efficient as Bresenham's algorithm.
result: The DDA algorithm is less precise and effective compared to Bresenham's algorithm.

original: Bresenham's algorithm is much accurate than the DDA algorithms.
result: Bresenham's algorithm is known for its higher level of precision compared to DDA algorithms.

original: DDA algorithm can draw circle and curves, but which is not as accurate as Bresenhams
result: The DDA algorithm is capable of drawing circles and curves, but its level of accuracy is inferior to that of Bresenham's algorithm.

original: Bresenhams algorithm can draw circle and curves with much more accuracy than DDA Algorithm.
result: Bresenham's algorithm is a method for drawing circles and curves that is more accurate than the DDA algorithm.

original: DDA algorithm uses an excessive number of floating-point multiplications, so it is costly.
result: The DDA algorithm is expensive due to its dependence on a lot of calculations involving floating-point multiplications.

original: Bresenhams algorithm is less costly than the DDA algorithm as it uses only addition and subtraction.
result: According to the comparison between Bresenham's algorithm and DDA algorithm, it is found that Bresenham's algorithm is more cost-effective as it utilizes only addition and subtraction compared to the DDA algorithm.

original: A translation is used to an object by repositioning it along a straight line path from one co-ordinate point to another. We translate a 2-D points by adding translation distance, tx, and ty, to the original coordinates position (x,y) to move the points to a new position (x', y').
result: To apply a translation to an object, it's necessary to move it from one coordinate point to another along a straight line path. When translating a 2-D point, the original position (x,y) is adjusted by adding the translation distance (tx, ty) to reach a new position (x', y').

original: x' = = x + t
result:
Rewritten: 

The new position, x', can be found by adding the time, t, to the original position, x.

original: A Reflection is a transformation which produces a mirror display of an object. The mirror image for a 2D reflection is created relative to an axis of reflection by rotating the objects 180 degrees about the reflection axis.
result: A reflection is a geometric transformation that generates a mirrored image of an object with respect to an axis of reflection. This mirror image is produced by rotating the object 180 degrees around the reflection axis to create a symmetrical representation of the original.

original: A transformation which distorts the shape of an object such that the transformed way develop as if the object were consist of internal layers that had been caused to slide over each other is known as shearing.
result: Shearing is a type of transformation where the shape of an object is altered in a way that makes it appear as if the object is made up of layers that have been shifted and overlapped.

original: The mapping of a component of a world-coordinate scene to device coordinates is called a viewing transformation.
result: A viewing transformation is the process of converting a segment of a scene in world coordinates to device coordinates through mapping.

original: Any method that identifies those portions of a display that are either inside or outside of a particular region of space is referred to as a clipping algorithm or simply clipping. The region against which an object is clipped is known a clip window.
result: A clipping algorithm or clipping is a technique for identifying parts of a display that are within or outside a specific area of space. The area against which an object is clipped is called a clip window.

original: In parallel projection, coordinate positions are changed to the view plane along parallel lines.
result: Parallel projection is a method of creating two-dimensional images of three-dimensional objects. It involves transforming the coordinates of the object to the view plane along lines that are parallel to each other. This technique is often used in engineering and architecture to create technical drawings and schematics.

original: In perspective projection, object positions are changed to the view plane along lines that converge to a point known as a projection reference point or center of projection.
result: Perspective projection involves altering the positions of objects onto the view plane by using lines that meet at a particular point referred to as the projection reference point or center of projection.

original: Preserves the related proportions of objects.
result: Maintains the same comparative sizes of items within a composition.

original: Produce realistic vision but does not keep relative proportions.
result: The output is a realistic representation but may not maintain accurate proportions.

original: It is used in drafting to produce scale drawings of 3Dobjects.
result: In the field of drafting, a tool is utilized to generate proportional drawings of three-dimensional objects known as a scale.

original: Projections of distant objects are lower than the projections of objects of the same size that are near to the projection plane.
result: Objects that are far away from the projection plane appear smaller than objects of the same size that are close to the projection plane.

original: Space partitioning representations are used to define interior methods, by partitioning the spatial domain including an object into a set of small non-overlapping, and contiguous solids. A common space partitioning description for a three object is an octree representation.
result: Space partitioning representations are a valuable tool for creating interior algorithms. They involve dividing the spatial domain of an object into numerous small and adjacent solids that do not overlap. One commonly used form of space partitioning is the octree representation, which is especially popular for rendering 3D objects.

original: Quadric surfaces are described with second-degree equations (quadrics). They include sphere, ellipsoids, tori, paraboloids, and hyperboloids. Spheres and ellipsoids are necessary components of graphic scenes; they are often feasible in graphics packages from which more complex object can be constructed.
result: Quadric surfaces are a family of surfaces defined by second-degree equations known as quadrics. They comprise of various shapes such as ellipsoids, spheres, hyperboloids, paraboloids, and tori. In graphics, spheres and ellipsoids are commonly used as fundamental objects to construct more complex shapes.

original: Frequency of light simulation at which it becomes perceived as a stable, continuous sensation. The frequency depends upon various factors like luminance, color, contrast, etc.
result: The rate at which light waves are emitted or received, leading to the steady perception of a continuing sensation, is referred to as the critical frequency of light. This frequency can be influenced by a variety of factors, such as brightness, color, and contrast.

original: A color model described with the primary colors cyan, magenta, and yellow (CMY) is useful for defining color output to hard-copy devices.
result: The CMY color model, which uses cyan, magenta, and yellow as primary colors, is a valuable tool for determining color output for printed materials.

original: The HSV model uses color descriptors that have a more natural appeal to the user. Color function in this model is hue (H), saturation (S) and value(V).
result: The HSV model is based on color descriptors that are more user-friendly and natural than other models. It uses hue (H), saturation (S), and value (V) as its primary color functions.

original: Hard-copy devices such as plotters produce a Color image by coating a paper with color pigments.
result: Color images can be produced on paper using hard-copy devices like plotters that apply color pigments onto the paper surface.

original: To give color specification, a user selects a spectral color and the amounts of black and white that are to be added to obtain different shades, tints, and tones.
result: To define a color, a person can choose a spectral hue and specify the proportions of black and white to be added in order to create various shades, tints, and tones.

original: The name dithering is used in different contexts. Primarily, it defines techniques for approximating halftones without reducing resolutions pixel: grid patterns do. But the term is also applied to halftone approximation methods using pixel grids and sometimes it is used to define to color halftone approximation only.
result: The term "dithering" has varied applications. It is commonly used to refer to methods used to create halftone patterns that appear continuous without reducing the resolution of an image, as such reduction can result in grid-like patterns. Additionally, the term can also be used to describe techniques that employ pixel grids to mimic halftones, or even be exclusively applied to color halftone approximation methods.

original: Random values added to pixel intensities to breakup contours are referred to as dither noise.
result: Dither noise is the term used for the addition of random values to pixel intensities, which helps to break up contours and create a more natural-looking image.

original: Computer Animation usually defines any time sequence of visual transformation in a scene. In adding to the dynamic area with translations or rotations, computer-generated animations could exhibit time innovation in object dimension, color, transparency, or surface texture. Animations often transition from one object shape to another.
result: Computer Animation refers to the process of displaying visual changes in a scene over time. This can involve transformations such as movements or rotations as well as alterations in object properties like color, texture, or transparency. Animations can also use shape modulation to change from one object form to another.

result: Please provide the content you would like me to paraphrase or rewrite.

original: Key-frame systems are specialized animation languages designed to generate the in-between frames from user-specified keyframes. Each object in the scene is described as a set of rigid bodies connected at the joints and with a limited number of degree of freedom. In-between frames are generated from the specification of two or more fey frames. Motion paths can be given by kinematic description as a set of spline curves or physically based by specifying the force acting on the object to be animated.
result: Key-frame systems refer to specialized animation languages that enable the creation of in-between frames based on user-provided keyframes. In these systems, each object in a given scene is defined as a group of rigid bodies connected at the joints, and with restricted degrees of freedom. In-between frames are then generated from the specification of two or more keyframes. Motion paths can be described kinematically using a set of spline curves, or physically based by outlining the force applied to the object being animated.

original: Fractals are those who have the property of a shape that has the same degree of roughness no matter how much it is magnified. A fractal appears the same at every scale.
result: Fractals are unique geometric shapes that possess a distinctive property of roughness, which remains constant even if the shape is magnified to any degree. These shapes are self-similar, appearing identical at every level of scale.

original: Turtle Graphics is a procedure in computer graphics for programming vector graphics utilizing a relative cursor upon a Cartesian plane. Turtle graphics is a vital characteristic of the Logo Programming language.
result: Turtle Graphics is a technique used in computer graphics for creating vector graphics with a cursor that moves relative to a Cartesian plane. This technique is an important feature of the Logo programming language.

original: The following functions describe the turtle.
result: Here are some functions that define the behavior of a turtle.

original: Position of the turtle (x, y)
result: Reworded: The current coordinates of the turtle, denoted as (x, y).

original: Title of the turtle 0 the angle from the x-axis.
result: Rename the turtle's heading as the degree measurement of its orientation from the x-axis.

original: Turtle graphics has three attribute
result: The attributes of turtle graphics are three in number.

original: For some functions, the boundary between those points that move towards those points that move towards infinity and those that tends toward a finite limit is a fractal. The boundary of the fractal is called the Julia set.
result: In certain mathematical functions, there exists a dividing line between points that move towards infinity and those that converge towards a finite value. This dividing line is known as the Julia set. Interestingly, the Julia set has a fractal shape.

original: It is the black inner fragment, which develops to consist of a cardioid along with several wart-like circles glued to it. Its border is complicated, and this complexity can be explored by zooming in on a portion of the border
result: The central component of the image appears black and takes on a roughly heart-shaped form. It is surrounded by a series of smaller, wart-like shapes which are intricately arranged and make up the border of the larger shape. Zooming in on any part of the border reveals its complex pattern and structure.

original: Julia sets are extremely complicated sets of points in the complex plane. There is a various Julia set Jc for each value of c.
result: Julia sets are highly intricate collections of points in the complex plane, with a unique Julia set Jc corresponding to each specific value of c.

original: The Koch curve can be drawn by separate line into 4 equal segments with scaling method 1/3., and middle 2 segments are so adapted that they form adjustment sides of an equilateral triangle.
result: To draw the Koch curve, you can divide each line into four equal parts using a scaling factor of 1/3. The two middle segments need to be adjusted to form the sides of an equilateral triangle.

original: Transformation of object shape from one form to another is known as morphing.
result: Morphing refers to the process of changing the shape of an object to another form.

original: Tweening is the process, which applies to animation objects defined by a sequence of points, and that change shape from frame to frame.
result: Tweening refers to a technique used in animation where objects that are defined by a series of points undergo a gradual transformation from one frame to the next. This gradual transformation results in a change in the shape of the object, which enhances the overall animation effect.

original: A fractal curve can fill the plane and therefore have a dimension of two. Such curves are called Peano curves.
result: A certain type of curve known as Peano curves can occupy all points in a plane, which gives them a dimension of two. These fractal curves are unique in their ability to fill the entire plane.

original: Scripting systems allow object specifications and animation sequences to be defined with a user input string. From the script, a library of different objects and motions can be constructed.
result: A scripting system is a tool that enables users to create specifications for objects and animation sequences using simple text input. By using these scripts, a range of objects and motions can be created and stored in a library for later use.

original: Picture definition is saved in a memory area known as the refresh buffer or frame buffer. This memory area keeps the set of intensity values for all the screen points.
result: The storage location for the definition of an image is referred to as the refresh buffer or frame buffer. It holds the array of intensity values for every pixel on the screen.

original: The frame buffer is where the image generation data is stored in the method of Video Display Monitors like CRT, Raster Scan, Random Scan, LCD, LED, etc.
result: The frame buffer is a storage area that holds the data used to generate images in various types of video display monitors, such as CRTs, Raster Scans, Random Scans, LCDs, and LEDs.

original: The maximum number of point that can be presented without overlap on a Cathode Ray Tube is indicated to as the resolutions.
result: The term "resolutions" refers to the highest number of points that can be displayed without overlapping on a cathode ray tube.

original: Resolution is the number of points per centimeters which can be plotted crosswise and vertically, although it is established as the total number of points in each direction.
result: Resolution refers to the amount of points that can be plotted horizontally and vertically per centimeter. The resolution is determined by counting the total number of points present in each direction.

original: A world-coordinate area selected for display is known as a window.
result: A term used in computer graphics to describe a specific location on a display screen is known as a window. This location is determined by its world-coordinate area.

original: An area on the display device to which a windows is mapped is known as a viewport.
result: A "viewport" refers to a specific section of the display screen that is assigned to a given window.

original: A portion of a picture that is to be presented by a window is known as Window port.
result: A window port refers to a section of an image that will be displayed through a window.

original: The display method of the part selected or the design in which the selected element is viewed is called a viewport.
result: A viewport refers to the method of displaying either a selected part or the design being viewed.

original: Some objects do not provide a fixed shape but change their surface features in certain motions or when in proximity to other objects. These objects are called as blobby objects since their shapes display a certain degree of fluidness.
result: There are certain objects that do not have a fixed shape and exhibit a malleable surface that changes in specific movements or when near other objects. These objects are commonly referred to as "blobby objects" due to their dynamic and fluid shape.

original: The name spline is a flexible strip used to generate a smooth curve through a designated set of points. In computer Graphics, the name spline curves define to any combined curve create with polynomial portions fulfilling specified continuity methods at the edge of the pieces.
result: A spline is a strip that is bendable and is utilized for producing smooth curves between specific points. In computer graphics, the term spline curves refers to any curve that is made by combining several polynomial pieces that satisfy particular continuity conditions at the boundaries of those pieces.

original: The degree of B-spline polynomial can be set separately of the number of control points.
result: The order of the B-spline polynomial and the number of control points can be independently defined.

original: B-Spline allows local authority over the shape of a spline curve or surface.
result: B-Spline is a mathematical technique that enables greater control over the shape of a curve or surface. It achieves this by allowing manipulation at the local level.

original: A Bezier curve is a particular polynomial task, usually either cubic or quadratic, that describes a curve that goes from point A to point B given some control points in between. A Bezier spline is a collection of n of these.
result: A Bezier curve is a type of mathematical function, typically cubic or quadratic, that outlines a path between two points using designated control points along the way. A Bezier spline is a group of multiple Bezier curves used in combination to create a complex curve or shape.

original: The phase of determining the appropriate pixels for representing images or graphics object is called a rasterization.
result: Rasterization refers to the process of selecting the most suitable pixels for rendering images or graphic elements.

original: The curve can be created from an input set of mathematical tasks defining the objects or from a set of user-specified points. When tasks are specified, a package can project the describing equations for a curve to the display plane and plot pixel methods along the path of the projected plane.
result: To generate a curve, there are two methods: one involves defining the mathematical tasks for the objects and the other requires user-specified points. In the former, a software package projects the equations onto the display plane and creates pixels based on the path of the projected plane.

original: The chromaticity diagram is generally used to calculate a color against a gamut. The assumption is that if the chromaticity of the color distortion within the gamut line, then the color maybe copied on that device, or maybe described by that color system.
result: The chromaticity diagram is a tool utilized for determining the color of a gamut. Its main purpose is to determine if a color falls within the gamut line. If so, the color can be reproduced on the device or be described by the color system being used.

original: Interactive computer Graphics like a website, it is only beneficial if a visitor browser it and no two visitors are precisely alike. It defines the website must provide the interaction of the customer with a variety of skills, interests, and end objective. Interactive computer graphics contains the user's interaction.
result: Interactive computer graphics are beneficial when they engage visitors and cater to their individual skills, interests, and goals. Similar to websites, no two visitors are exactly alike, so providing interaction is crucial. The user's involvement is a key feature of interactive computer graphics.

original: RGB is a color model; it is an additive color image in which red, green, and blue lights are added composed in various methods to reproduce a broad display of colors. The term of the model comes from the labels of the three additive primary colors, red, green, and blue. The main objective of the RGB color model is for the sensing, defining, and display of pictures in electronic systems, such as televisions and computers, though it has also been utilizing in conventional photography.
result: The RGB color model is a type of color model that uses the additive system to create a vast array of colors through a combination of red, green, and blue lights. This model is commonly used in electronic systems such as televisions and computers but is also applicable in photography. Its name comes from the initials of the three primary colors used, R for red, G for green, and B for blue. The RGB model is primarily used for sensing, defining, and displaying images in digital systems.

original: A monitor or display known as a visual display unit is a portion of electrical machinery which displays images created by an appliance such as computers, without producing a permanent data. The monitor composes the display device, circuitry, and an enclosure. The display device in modern monitors is usually a thin film transistor liquid crystal display (TFT-LCD), while previous monitors use a cathode ray tube (CRT).
result: A visual display unit or monitor is an electronic device that shows images generated by a computer or other machines, without storing the data permanently. It comprises of a display device, an enclosure, and circuitry. In modern monitors, the display device is typically a TFT-LCD, whereas older ones use a CRT.

original: The process of displaying 3D into a 2D display unit is called a projection. The projection changes 3D objects into a 2D projection plane.
result: The act of converting three-dimensional visuals into a two-dimensional display is referred to as a projection. This procedure involves transforming 3D objects into a 2D projection surface.

original: They are quicker than pen plotters and large-quality printers.
result: Unlike pen plotters and large-quality printers, these machines are designed to operate at a faster pace.

original: New electrostatic plotters contain a scan-conversion capability.
result: The latest electrostatic plotters now come equipped with a capability for scan-conversion.

original: Color electrostatic plotters are feasible. They make different passes over the paper to plot color images.
result: Electrostatic plotters that can produce color images are possible. They work by making multiple passes over the paper to create various hues.

original: Large speed, precision, and economy.
result: The characteristics of a desirable system include fast speed, accurate precision, and efficient use of resources.

original: Lasts for high time.
result: Has a prolonged duration.

original: Toner power is very in-expensive.
result: The cost of toner powder is relatively low.

original: Addressability is the number of particular dots per inch (d.p.i.) that can be developed. If the location of the current dot is (x, y), then the next dot will be (x + y), (x + y + 1), etc.
result: Addressability refers to the resolution or density of dots per inch (d.p.i.) that can be created. Each dot's precise location is determined by its coordinates, such as (x, y), which then determines the position of the next dot in the succession, such as (x + y), (x + y + 1), and so on.

original: When the key is pressed on the keyboard, the keyboard auditor places a code import to the key pressed into a part of memory called a keyboard buffer. This code is known as the scan-code.
result: When a keyboard button is pressed, the keyboard auditor records a code that corresponds to the pressed key, known as a scan-code, and stores it in a section of memory called the keyboard buffer.
